discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We can make a multiplication from the outset, but we can also use mathematical induction which, in this case, is quicker. The first line, the amount of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" in square is two digits, hence the square being from 1 to 2 then reverse (without repetition of 2) to 1. Similarly, in the second line, the amount of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" in square is three digits, hence the square being from 1 to 3 then reverse (without repetition of 3) to 1."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hence, the amount of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" in square is five digits, hence the square being from 1 to 5 then reverse (without repetition of 5) to 1, or by spelling out, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"123454321"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: "When I was 4"
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large{xy+\frac{x^3+y^3}{3}=2007}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ordered pairs "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(x,y)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" of integers satisfying the equation above.
If the set of all such pairs are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \{ (x_1, y_1), (x_2, y_2), \ldots , (x_n, y_n) \} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then find the value of:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large{\sum_{i=1}^n (x_i + y_i) = \ ? }"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We use the factorisation "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^3+y^3+z^3-3xyz=(x+y+z)(x^2+y^2+z^2-xy-yz-zx)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned} \dfrac{x^3+y^3}{3} +xy &= 2007\\
x^3+y^3+3xy &= 6021\\
x^3+y^3+(-1)^3 - 3xy(-1) &= 6020\\
(x+y-1)(x^2+y^2+1-xy+x+y) &= 6020\\
(x+y-1)((x+y-1)^2 - 3xy - 3x - 3y) &= 2^2 \times 5 \times 7 \times 43
\end{aligned}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since the RHS "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\equiv 2 \pmod{3}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", the LHS must also be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\equiv 2 \pmod{3}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Thus, we must have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x+y-1 \equiv 2 \pmod{3}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". All positive factors of 6020 that are equivalent to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2 \pmod{3}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"14"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"20"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"35"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"86"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"140"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"215"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"602"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"860"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1505"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"6020"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". By observation, we get that only "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x+y-1=20"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" satisfies, with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=18"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y=3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" or vice-versa. Thus, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x+y=21"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", but since we're looking for ordered pairs, the answer is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{42}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

                                            This solution is similar to the solution in mathematical treasures by titu andreescu.

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 6021 =x^3 + y^3 + 3xy = (x+y)^3 - 3xy(x+y) + 3xy "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
we see that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x+y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is divisible by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". But then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3xy = 6021 + 3xy(x+y) - (x+y)^3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is divisible by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"9"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" divides "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"xy"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Thus both "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are divisible by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=3X"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y=3Y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" where
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \begin{aligned}
6021 & = \; 27(X+Y)^3 - 81XY(X+Y) + 27XY \\
27XY & = \; \frac{27(X+Y)^3 - 6021}{3(X+Y) - 1} \; = \; 9(X+Y)^2 + 3(X+Y) + 1 - \frac{6020}{3(X+Y)-1}
\end{aligned} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
so we deduce that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3(X+Y)-1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" divides "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"6020"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Possible values of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X+Y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and therefore "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"XY"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", are thus"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline
X+Y & XY & X+Y & XY & X+Y & XY & X+Y & XY \\ \hline
-1003 & 335225 & -401 & 53556 & -143 & 6801 & -100 & 3323 \\
-57 & 1078 & -23 & 177 & -14 & 69 & -9 & 34 \\
-3 & 25 & -2 & 33 & -1 & 56 & 0 & 223 \\
1 & -111 & 2 & -43 & 5 & -7 & 7 & 6 \\
12 & 43  &29 & 281 & 47 & 740 & 72 & 1735 \\
201 & 13489 & 287 & 27488 & 502 & 84057 & 2007 & 1342906  \\ \hline
\end{array} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Of these, only the pair "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X+Y=7"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"XY= 6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" correspond to integer solutions "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X,Y = 1,6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Thus the only solutions to the equation are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(x_1,y_1) = (18,3)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(x_2,y_2) = (3,18)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which makes the answer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{42}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

replies.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Oh and here the factorization is actually quite trivial, remember the identity "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" x^3 + y^3 + z^3 - 3xyz = (x + y + z)(x^2 + y^2 + z^2 - xy - yz - zx) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", now it is easy to see that by choosing "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"z = -1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  we get  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" x^3 + y^3 - 1 + 3xy = (x + y - 1)(x^2 + y^2 + 1 - xy + y + x) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In general we could look for a possible linear factor "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" (ax + by + c) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to the polynomial and if that fails, quadratic, and so on with multiple variables also.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Yes you could fact this way. It was interesting, nonetheless, to note that both "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" had to be multiples of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Couldn't you already use "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 3xy = 6021 + 3xy(x+y) - (x+y)^3 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to get  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 3xy = ((x+y)^2 + (x + y) + 1) - \dfrac{6020}{ (x + y) - 1 } "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" which leads to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" x + y - 1 \mid 6020"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"?"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Your method of solving this is similar to finding a factorization "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" (x + y - 1)(x^2 - xy + y^2 + x + y + 1) = 6020 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"which simplifies the problem of solving "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" x^3 + 3xy + y^3 = 6021 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to factoring the left hand side of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" x^3 + 3xy + y^3 + C = 6021 + C "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for some constant "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"C"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" which again is a common method of solving diophantine equations.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}
